pullRequest.body:
Implements the `pnat_to_nat` and `enat_to_nat` tactics, which translate arithmetic (only `+`, `-`, and `*` so far) and order from `PNat` and `ENat` to `Nat`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [2c8a684c6e](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21602/commits/2c8a684c6eac3416e2aed43af18b2d47848d608c)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Tactic`|2|
| `Mathlib.Tactic.PNatToNat` (new file)|445|
| `Mathlib.Tactic.ENatToNat` (new file)|488|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ coe_add`
`+ coe_inj`
`+ coe_le_coe`
`+ coe_lt_coe`
`+ coe_mul`
`+ coe_ofNat`
`+ coe_one`
`+ coe_sub`
`+ coe_zero`
`+ not_lt_top`
`+ sub_coe`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](https://speed.lean-lang.org/mathlib4/run-detail/dfcbaaaf-c6ef-40c2-92b6-28bec5c35e42) for commit 8de6671f67405484db50fc8730d7cbaa11676dca.
There were [no significant changes](https://speed.lean-lang.org/mathlib4/compare/2c3a7fee-355f-41ce-817d-1c949481d3cb/to/dfcbaaaf-c6ef-40c2-92b6-28bec5c35e42) against commit 5c57f97198cbc1377e262ee88fa359e3670e6822.

|File|Instructions|%|
|-|-:|:-:|
|`build`|+80.795⬝10⁹|(+0.05%)|
|`Mathlib.Data.Array.Lemmas`|-1.240⬝10⁹|(-26.09%)|
[CI run](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13238849312)

Personally, I think `nify_pnat` / `nify_enat` might make more sense for the names to match `zify`/`qify`/`rify`, but someone that's a mathlib reviewer should say what they think. `nify_*` is a deviation from the names of those tactics anyway, but I imagine in the future we will want more of these, e.g. at least for Fin as well, so it might be nice to make them 'close' to each other.

> Personally, I think `nify_pnat` / `nify_enat` might make more sense for the names to match `zify`/`qify`/`rify`, but someone that's a mathlib reviewer should say what they think. `nify_*` is a deviation from the names of those tactics anyway, but I imagine in the future we will want more of these, e.g. at least for Fin as well, so it might be nice to make them 'close' to each other.

I prefer the current names.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13488716227/job/37683434089)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13488716227/job/37683434219)
This pollutes the context by renaming *everything*, not just what you are calling cases on.
Can you use (the internals of) the `cases_type` tactic?
The reason why I use the `cases` tactic here is that is able to pick the right `cases_eliminator` for `ENat`, while `cases_type` always uses the default one.

```suggestion
```
Update `OmegaExtensions`
Update OmegaExtensions
ditto
Slight preference for these just to be called `enat_to_nat`, etc. This will align with the naming scheme I'm using in Lean.

Scratch that, I missed that there were two simp sets.

I prefer removing the `_simps`, I guess -- this is implicit in it being a simp_attr.

```suggestion
elab "cases_first_enat" : tactic => focus do
```
Seems a bit weird to use `repeat'`. Couldn't your custom cases tactic handle doing this itself? This would also say repeatedly calling `simp` inside `cases_first_ENat`.
I don't think I understand your comment. What is wrong with the current approach? And I already call `simp only [enat_to_nat_top]` inside `cases_first_enat`.

Sorry, typo in my comment, I meant to say: "this would **save** repeatedly calling `simp`"

In particular I see that 
```
all_goals try simp only [enat_to_nat_top] at *
```
is going to be called on the whole context for each `ENat` hypothesis, but it should be possible to just call it once after all the casing is finished.
I understand now. In fact, I interleave casing with this `simp` because some goals may already be closed, for example, if they contain a `⊤ < x` hypothesis. This reduces branching.
I wonder if it is worth checking if such hypotheses already exist, thereby making the tactic idempotent.
This one could be called just `pnat_to_nat`.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Tactic): `pnat_to_nat` and `enat_to_nat` tactics
